section.title: Advanced techniques with onCourse
section.para: Other than directly editing the content of pages within your site, there are a number of other parts of your site you might like to edit. These things can be accessed from the toolbar: Site Settings, Blocks, Pages, Menus and Themes.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The onCourse website CMS allows users to manage a number of different aspects of how their website and portal displays information.

This includes determining which fields are display within online forms, what information can be viewed through the Skills onCourse portal and it allows the addition of social media links. These options can be accessed by clicking on the Site Settings tab within the CMS.

caption.para: CMS Site Settings menu options and link to onCourse CMS User Handbook

section.title: Contact entry
section.para: This page enables users to determine whether fields within the Enrolment and Mailing list online forms are shown or hidden, as well as the ability to set a given field as mandatory. You can also set whether or not the AVETMISS questions should display at the bottom of the Enrolment Form.
Please note that the fields for First Name, Last Name and Email address are the minimum required fields that can be displayed and therefore these fields cannot be edited.

caption.para: Manage the display of fields within the enrolment and mailing list forms

section.title: Setting Enrolment Minimum Age
section.para: If a particular Class has a minimum age requirement, you can now set this via the Site Settings / Contact Entry view of the CMS. Simply add the minimum age as a year to the CMS field, as well as setting the Date of Birth field as 'required'. The enrolling student will then need to supply a valid date of birth and if that date is less than the minimum enrolment age, the system will display a validation error message to the student within the online form.

caption.para: Validation message if student is younger than minimum age

section.title: Gathering Missing Contact Details for Existing Students
section.para: You could have a scenario whereby you have an existing student who enrols in a given Class via the website, but you do not have a mobile telephone number for them recorded within onCourse database.

By setting the mobile phone field to a status of 'Required' within the Contact Entry view of your CMS Site Settings, this will then allow you to gather this information from the existing student within the online enrolment process. This works on the basis that if the field is set to required, and the existing contact does not have any information against the field, then the student is asked to supply a mobile phone number as part of their online enrolment process.

section.title: Skills onCourse
section.para: The CMS settings page allows Colleges to manage the amount of information that is able to be viewed by Tutors on the Skills onCourse portal. It is also possible to specify as to which email address tutor feedback is sent to within the College.

caption.para: Manage the information that tutors can access via the tutor portal

section.para: When viewing the class roll via the Skills onCourse, Colleges can determine whether they want their tutors to be able to view the email address, phone numbers of each student on the class roll. Please note that it is not possible to not display the contact details for one class, but display it for another, as this setting is universally applied.

See the following screen from the Skills onCourse portal which shows where the student contact details display within the class roll. By specifying that you do not want the contact details to be displayed, this class list would simply show as a list of student names.

caption.para: Manage the display of student email and telephone contacts within the class roll on Skills onCourse

section.title: Website
section.para: The onCourse CMS now gives you access to a powerful social media linking tool called 'Add This'. This free application will enable a college to insert social media links into courses and web pages, as well as giving you access to analytical tools to gain insight into your audience.

In order to add these social media links, you need to set up a free account with 'Add This', including specifying which social media links you wish to display on your website, the size and format of those links, as well as the free analytics tools that are part of your account set up.

Once you have set up the 'Add This' account by following the link within the CMS, all you need to do to insert the id into the field provided and then specify as to whether you wish these links to appear on your course description and or web page.

section.title: Blocks
section.para: Blocks are the cornerstone to your website's variety and page dynamics. For example if you wanted an element (a banner for example) on every page of your web site, then blocks are your answer. If you wanted an area on several different pages dedicated to a contact form, blocks are ideal. Blocks are re-usable snippets of text, pictures, rich text markup, javascript, etc.

The block listing page allows you to easily add and edit blocks. Give them a name which means something to you as users of the website will never see the name. section.title: Pages
section.para: This list of all the pages in your site gives you quick access to find the page you need, then edit or delete that page. The search box to the top right gives you quick access to find pages by name.

section.title: Menus
section.para:
Drag and Drop Menu hierarchy
Most websites will have a primary navigation menu which users will use to find their way around. In this place you can add new menu items, and link them to particular pages or external URLs. The user interface here is very simple: click on the menu name to edit it. The name is visible to users of your website. Drag the menu items into a different order or nest them within other menu items. And click to edit the URL (that is, the page to which the menu links).

section.title: Themes
section.para:
Themes - adding variety
Themes are a way to describe a page structure made up by a number of blocks and by a design layout created for you by your designer. There will always be a layout called "default" available and many sites will need no more than just that one layout. If you want different parts of your site to have very different looks, ask your designer to create alternative layouts for you to use.
Each theme can have a number of blocks arranged in any way you choose. There are five regions available: header left content right footer

Each region can contain one or more blocks which you drag from the right area. To remove a block just drag it back into the list of unused blocks on the right. You can order the blocks on the page by dragging them into the position of your choice. Remember, that when the page is shown the content area will also contain any content for the page itself. The blocks are shown above the page content, although your web designer can change that if they choose.
